conclusion: Use the relationship between velocity and displacement to find the time taken for the detector to move from point A to point B.
The image shows a line segment on the x-axis from point O to point B, with points A and B marked along this segment.
The velocity of the detector is inversely proportional to its displacement, so \( v = \frac{k}{x} \).
At point A, the velocity \( v_A = 4 \, \text{m/s} \), so \( 4 = \frac{k}{x_A} \). Solving for \( k \), we get \( k = 4x_A \).
At point B, the velocity \( v_B = 2 \, \text{m/s} \), so \( 2 = \frac{k}{x_B} \). Substituting \( k = 4x_A \), we have \( 2 = \frac{4x_A}{x_B} \).
Given \( x_B = 2 \, \text{m} \), solve for \( x_A \): \( 2 = \frac{4x_A}{2} \) implies \( x_A = 1 \, \text{m} \).
The time taken for the detector to move from point A to point B is given by \( t = \frac{x_B - x_A}{v_A} \).
